concepts.title: Literary Devices â€” Simile, Metaphor, Alliteration
concepts.content: A simile compares two different things using 'as' or 'like' (e.g., 'as tall as a tree'). A metaphor makes a direct comparison without 'as' or 'like' (e.g., 'Books are our friends'). Alliteration is when the same sound appears at the beginning of two or more words in a line (e.g., 'Nayna needs new notebooks').

examples.text: Simile: 'Charging along like troops in a battle'
Metaphor: 'The future is a sea beneath a cloudless sun'
Alliteration: 'In time of silver rain' (silver, singing)
Metaphor: 'Time is money'; 'The clouds are white sheep'

keyPoints: Simile: comparison using 'as' or 'like'
Metaphor: direct comparison without 'as'/'like'
Alliteration: same sound at start of 2+ words in a line
Literary devices make poetry vivid and imaginative
Emily BrontÃ« uses 3 metaphors in 'Past, Present, Future'

concepts.title: Poetry â€” 'Past, Present, Future' and 'In Time of Silver Rain'
concepts.content: Emily BrontÃ«'s 'Past, Present, Future' uses nature to describe time through a child's eyes â€” past is an autumn evening, present is a bird gathering strength, future is a glorious sea. Langston Hughes's 'In Time of Silver Rain' celebrates how rain brings new life, joy and growth.

examples.text: Past: 'An autumn evening soft and mild'
Present: 'A young bird gathering its power to fly'
Future: 'A mighty, glorious, dazzling sea'
Silver rain: 'The earth puts forth new life again'

keyPoints: Emily BrontÃ«: 19th century British poet, uses nature as metaphor
Langston Hughes: American writer, started new rhythmic poetry style
Rhyming pairs: thee/free, spray/away, sky/fly
Rhythm: the regular beat that makes poetry musical
Intonation: rise and fall of voice while reading aloud
concepts.funFact: ðŸŒ§ï¸ Langston Hughes wrote about rain bringing joy because he believed nature's cycles mirror human emotions â€” both need renewal!
concepts.textbookRef: Pages 1-2: Past, Present, Future; Pages 8-9: In Time of Silver Rain

concepts.title: Story â€” 'Odd One In' (Accepting Differences)
concepts.content: In 'Odd One In' by Tithi Tavora, Rima mocks Malti for her appearance and accent. But Malti proves her intelligence and talent through mathematics and singing. The story teaches us not to judge people by their appearance or the way they speak. True worth is shown through actions.

examples.text: Malti wins the singing competition despite being mocked
Malti excels at maths â€” her 'forte' (strength)
Rima feels no joy even winning, knowing she was unkind
Lesson: judge people by character, not appearance or accent

keyPoints: Prejudice: judging others based on appearance or accent
Forte: a person's strongest skill
Snob: someone who looks down on others
Clique: a small exclusive group
Language learning takes time â€” respect those learning
concepts.funFact: ðŸŒ India has 22 official languages and hundreds of dialects â€” everyone is 'Malti' in some language!
concepts.textbookRef: Pages 3-7: Odd One In by Tithi Tavora

concepts.title: Fable â€” 'The King's Choice' (Wisdom and Kindness)
concepts.content: In this fable, a lion king wants camel meat and his courtiers (fox, leopard, vulture) serve only their own interests. The clever fox brings the camel safely home. When the courtiers try to trick the camel into offering itself as food, the wise lion sees through them and rewards the loyal camel with friendship. 'To be king is good. But to be kind is better.'

examples.text: Fox's cleverness: runs into desert, finds camel, brings help
Camel's loyalty: offers his life honestly without cunning
Lion's wisdom: sees through false offers, rewards true loyalty
Moral: 'To be king is good. But to be kind is better.'

keyPoints: Fable: a story with animals that teaches a moral lesson
Court: adviser, bodyguard, messenger around a king
Oath of loyalty: a promise to serve faithfully
Self-interest vs. true loyalty: key theme
Kindness is greater than power
concepts.funFact: ðŸ¦ Aesop wrote animal fables 2500 years ago â€” the same storytelling technique that 'The King's Choice' uses to teach wisdom!
concepts.textbookRef: Pages 10-15: The King's Choice by Shankar

concepts.title: Grammar â€” Types of Nouns and Formal Invitations
concepts.content: Nouns are divided into common nouns (general names: girl, city) and proper nouns (specific names: Mumbai, Rima â€” always capitalized). They can also be countable (boy/boys) or uncountable (water, hair). A formal invitation must include: who is inviting, what the programme is, date, time, venue, and a polite request.

examples.text: Common noun: girl, city, river | Proper noun: Malti, Mumbai
Countable: bookâ†’books; Uncountable: water, milk, fun
Formal invite: 'We solicit your presence at the Inauguration...'
Oral invitation: polite, covers all 8 key points (who, what, when, where...)

keyPoints: Common noun: general name (girl, city, river)
Proper noun: specific name, always capitalised (Mumbai, Rima)
Countable: can be singular/plural (book/books)
Uncountable: cannot be counted (water, hair, fun)
Formal invitation: 8 points â€” who, what, chief guest, presiding, time, venue, etc.
concepts.funFact: ðŸ“¬ Indian school invitations use the phrase 'We solicit your presence' â€” 'solicit' means to politely ask or request!
concepts.textbookRef: Pages 7, 15: Nouns; Pages 16-20: Seeing Eyes Helping Hands (Invitations)

test.question: In Emily BrontÃ«'s poem, the future is compared to _____.
options: A sea beneath a cloudless sun
A young bird on a spray
test.explanation: 'The future, happy one? A sea beneath a cloudless sun; A mighty, glorious, dazzling sea stretching into infinity.'

test.question: What literary device is used in 'Books are our friends'?
test.explanation: A metaphor directly compares two things without using 'as' or 'like'. 'Books are our friends' says books ARE friends, not 'like' friends.

test.question: In 'Odd One In', what was Malti's greatest strength?
test.explanation: Her forte was mathematics â€” she was bright, studious and intelligent, and many girls sought her help in maths.

test.question: What is the moral of 'The King's Choice'?
options: To be kind is better than to be king
The fox is the most loyal animal
test.explanation: The lion king himself thinks: 'To be king is good. But to be kind is better.' â€” the story's central message.

test.question: Which of these is a proper noun?
test.explanation: Proper nouns are specific names of particular persons, places or things and are always capitalised. 'Swami Vivekananda' is a specific person's name.

test.question: 'Charging along like troops in a battle' â€” what literary device is this?
test.explanation: A simile compares two things using 'like' or 'as'. The train is compared to troops using 'like'.

test.question: Who was Swami Vivekananda addressing when he said 'Sisters and brothers of America!'?
test.explanation: Swami Vivekananda made his famous speech at the Parliament of World's Religions, receiving a two-minute standing ovation.

test.question: In 'The King's Choice', why did the fox and leopard agree the vulture should lead to the desert?
options: They didn't want to seem less wise than the vulture
They knew the way to the desert
They were frightened of the camel
test.explanation: The fox and leopard did not know the desert but didn't want the vulture to seem wiser than them, so they said it was the vulture's idea and he should lead.

test.question: 'Nayna needs new notebooks' â€” what device is used?
test.explanation: Alliteration is when the same sound appears at the beginning of two or more words. Here, 'N' sound repeats: Nayna, needs, new, notebooks.

test.question: A formal invitation must include _____.
options: All of: who, what, date, time, venue and polite request
Just the name of the chief guest
Only the school name and time
test.explanation: A complete formal invitation covers 8 points: who is inviting, what the programme is, name of inaugurator, presiding person, date, time, venue, and a polite request to attend.

keyConcepts: Alliteration: same initial sound in 2+ words
Emily BrontÃ«: nature metaphors for time (past/present/future)
Langston Hughes: rain brings new life â€” rhythmic poetry
Odd One In: do not judge by appearance or accent
The King's Choice: kindness > power; true loyalty rewarded
Common vs proper nouns; countable vs uncountable nouns
Formal invitation: 8 points (who, what, chief guest, presiding, time, venue)
commonMisconceptions: All comparisons are similes â€” FALSE, metaphors compare without 'as'/'like'
Proper nouns are only people's names â€” FALSE, places and organisations too
Uncountable nouns have plural forms â€” FALSE, we say 'glass of water' not 'waters'
Rima was a bad student â€” FALSE, she came first in her singing category
realWorldExamples: Mumbai: proper noun; city: common noun
School invitations â€” formal vs informal difference
Judging classmates by language skills vs actual intelligence
Seasonal rains in India (monsoon) â€” connect to 'In Time of Silver Rain'
Swami Vivekananda's Parliament of World's Religions speech

longAnswers.question: What literary device is used in 'Books are our friends'?
longAnswers.modelAnswer: In the sentence â€˜Books are our friendsâ€™, the device is metaphor. A metaphor directly identifies one thing as another to show a shared quality. Here, books are not literally human friends, but they guide, comfort, and support us. So the comparison is implied, not made with â€˜likeâ€™ or â€˜asâ€™.
keyPoints: The device is metaphor.
Metaphor makes an implied comparison.
Books are shown as supportive companions.
No â€˜likeâ€™ or â€˜asâ€™ is used.

longAnswers.question: In 'Odd One In', what was Malti's greatest strength?
longAnswers.modelAnswer: In â€˜Odd One Inâ€™, Maltiâ€™s greatest strength was her self-belief and positive attitude. Even when she lacked resources, she did not lose confidence or stop trying. She used her time and opportunities wisely and kept learning. This inner determination helped her move ahead.
keyPoints: Maltiâ€™s key strength was self-confidence.
She stayed positive despite difficulties.
She used time and effort effectively.
Determination led to her progress.

longAnswers.question: What is the moral of 'The King's Choice'?
longAnswers.modelAnswer: The moral of â€˜The Kingâ€™s Choiceâ€™ is that wisdom and honesty are more valuable than pride and outward show. The story shows that true leadership requires good judgment, humility, and concern for others. Those who act only for status make poor decisions. Therefore, character matters more than appearance.
keyPoints: Wisdom and honesty are central values.
Leadership needs humility and judgment.
Pride leads to wrong choices.
Character is greater than outward status.

longAnswers.question: 'Charging along like troops in a battle' â€” what literary device is this?
longAnswers.modelAnswer: The line â€˜Charging along like troops in a battleâ€™ uses a simile. A simile compares two unlike things with words such as â€˜likeâ€™ or â€˜asâ€™. Here, movement is compared to marching troops to create a vivid picture of speed and force. This makes the description lively and dramatic.
keyPoints: The device is simile.
Simile uses â€˜likeâ€™ or â€˜asâ€™.

longAnswers.question: In 'The King's Choice', why did the fox and leopard agree the vulture should lead to the desert?
longAnswers.modelAnswer: In â€˜The Kingâ€™s Choiceâ€™, the fox and leopard wanted to avoid responsibility for choosing the difficult desert route. They feared blame if the plan failed, so they pushed the vulture forward as the guide. At the same time, they tried to protect their own image before the king. Their choice was driven more by self-interest than wisdom.
keyPoints: Fox and leopard avoided responsibility.
They shifted risk to the vulture.
They were concerned about blame and image.
Their action showed self-interest.

longAnswers.question: 'Nayna needs new notebooks' â€” what device is used?
longAnswers.modelAnswer: â€˜Nayna needs new notebooksâ€™ is an example of alliteration. Alliteration is the repetition of the same initial consonant sound in nearby words. In this sentence, the â€˜nâ€™ sound repeats in Nayna, needs, new, and notebooks. This repetition gives rhythm and emphasis.
keyPoints: The device is alliteration.
Initial consonant sound is repeated.
